headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Alex Murdaugh Faces Day Two of Cross-Examination; President Zelenskyy Speaks as Ukraine Marks One Year of War; Secretary Antony Blinken Addresses U.N. Security Council One Year After Russia's Invasion. Aired 10:30-11a ET

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, MURDER DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: That I lied to people that trusted me.

utterances.speaker: CREIGHTON WATERS, PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: So, we can agree that the prosecution and law enforcement, and so many of your friends and family heard for the first time your story about the kennels yesterday after all these weeks of testimony. Can we agree on that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The law enforcement, my partners and my friends heard me say that for the first time. Yes, I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Would you agree with me that your own lawyer was repeating your story that you were at home napping as late as November of 2022 on national television?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't know that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. In jail, we don't get newspapers and the TV we have is limited. So.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So your own lawyers as late as November 2022 didn't know this story that you've told to this jury after five weeks of your family and friends coming in and saying, yes, that's him on that video.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Objection, your honor. Violation of attorney-client privilege, communication. Totally improper.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. Your response.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: He has brought up his communications with counsel and now that is fair game, your honor. His communications through counsel or alleged communication with the prosecution.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There is no attorney-client privilege to national television interviews. The objection is overruled. MURDAUGHanswer?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I think the point is made.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: All right, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You said you were unaware of that national television interview, is that what you said?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Unaware of what national television interview?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The one where your lawyer repeated that story as late as November of 2022, your story that you were actually at home asleep at the house?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The only national TV ad that I am aware of is -- not ad, program is one that Mr. Griffin was involved in was a -- are you referring to like a "Dateline" something?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'm talking about HBO.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: OK. HBO, like, so, yes, I am aware of that, and what I believe the case to be is that I believe that when that was in its works that Mr. Griffin made those statements some time substantially before November of '22, as early as around the very beginning of 2021.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Let's talk --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: At least what I understand to be the case.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Let's talk some more about your testimony yesterday. And you're telling this jury even on something as clear as this kennel video, that your story doesn't change when you have to make them to fit the facts that no longer can be denied. Is that what you're telling this jury?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't understand that question. Say that again?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I said, you're telling this jury that you don't change your story to make the facts fit evidence you can no longer deny like what has been going on in this courtroom.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not telling the jury anything about that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Good. All right, let's move on, let's talk some more about that issue. Let's talk about the confrontation on June 7th --

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Moving now to New York from Kyiv, U.S. Secretary of State speaking. Let's listen in.

utterances.speaker: KYLIE ATWOOD, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, the secretary of State very clearly stating that Russia failed its primary objective in Ukraine, and what he did was took stock in terms of what has happened over the last year, reminding all of these countries that he stood before the United Nations about a year ago this time warning that Russia was going to create some sort of false flag operation, that it was going to invade Ukraine, even though Russia denied that it was going to do so.And then what he did was reflect on how Ukraine has responded, saying that Ukraine's spirit today is unbroken, that Ukraine is stronger than ever, thank the international community for standing by Ukraine and also supporting efforts to make sure that global food insecurity and all of the fallout from this Ukraine war is supported by the rest of the world. And I think that it's important to note that the secretary of State also made sure that there needs to be a just and durable peace going forward.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: And indeed Russia did try those false flag operations. U.S. exposed them. They didn't hit their mark.Alex Marquardt, standing by in Kyiv. Alex, I wonder if the Ukrainians you're speaking with are bracing themselves for this war to drag on for months and perhaps years.

utterances.speaker: ALEX MARQUARDT, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Jim. Jim, I absolutely think they are. Today is certainly a day of reflection for everybody who's endured this war. The millions of Ukrainians who've endured this war over the past year. It's a day of sadness because they recognize that the war indeed will continue for quite some time.There are so many parts of this country that have returned to, you know, some kind of normalcy. There are cities where people have gone back to life, that people who had left the country have returned to, whether it's Lviv or Kyiv or Odessa or here where I am in Dnipro. But this is not a normal life. This is a time when air-raid sirens are going off all the time. Attacks, missile attacks, drone attacks taking place all across the country. And of course in the eastern part of the country, towns and the cities have been decimated. This war is essentially at a standstill, that frontline is quite stagnant, it is grinding, and it is active. And so there is a recognition that it is going to be quite some time before the Russian forces can be pushed out. That's why President Zelenskyy is saying time is of the essence to get that foreign aid into Ukraine as fast as possible -- Jim, Kristin.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Also in the meantime. Alex Marquardt there, Kylie Atwood in New York, thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: And thank you, Jim, for letting me spend the week with you here on set here.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: It's been great to have you.

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: It's been great to be here. I'm Kristin Fisher.
